Consistent query answers on numerical databases
under aggregate constraints

Sergio Flesca ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Filippo Furfaro ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Francesco Parisi
Abstract

The problem of extracting consistent information from relational databases violating integrity constraints on numerical data is addressed. In particular, aggregate constraints defined as linear inequalities on aggregate-sum queries on input data are considered. The notion of repair as consistent set of updates at attribute-value level is exploited, and the characterization of several complexity issues related to repairing data and computing consistent query answers is provided.

1 Introduction

Research has deeply investigated several issues related to the use of integrity constraints on relational databases. In this context, a great deal of attention has been devoted to the problem of extracting reliable information from databases containing pieces of information inconsistent w.r.t. some integrity constraints. All previous works in this area deal with ‚Äúclassical‚Äù forms of constraint (such as keys, foreign keys, functional dependencies), and propose different strategies for updating inconsistent data reasonably, in order to make it consistent by means of minimal changes. Indeed these kinds of constraint often do not suffice to manage data consistency, as they cannot be used to define algebraic relations between stored values. In fact, this issue frequently occurs in several scenarios, such as scientific databases, statistical databases, and data warehouses, where numerical values of tuples are derivable by aggregating values stored in other tuples.

In this work we focus our attention on databases where stored data violates a set of aggregate constraints, i.e. integrity constraints defined on aggregate values extracted from the database. These constraints are defined on numerical attributes (such as sales prices, costs, etc.) which represent measure values and are not intrinsically involved in other forms of constraints.

Example 1

Table 1 represents a two-years cash budget for a firm, that is a summary of cash flows (receipts, disbursements, and cash balances) over the specified periods. Values ‚Äòdet‚Äô, ‚Äòaggr‚Äô and ‚Äòdrv‚Äô in column Type stand for detail, aggregate and derived, respectively. In particular, an item of the table is aggregate if it is obtained by aggregating items of type detail of the same section, whereas a derived item is an item whose value can be computed using the values of other items of any type and belonging to any section.

A cash budget must satisfy these integrity constraints:

  • 1.

    for each section and year, the sum of the values of all detail items must be equal to the value of the aggregate item of the same section and year;

  • 2.

    for each year, the net cash inflow must be equal to the difference between total cash receipts and total disbursements;

  • 3.

    for each year, the ending cash balance must be equal to the sum of the beginning cash and the net cash balance.

Table 1 was acquired by means of an OCR tool from two paper documents, reporting the cash budget for 2003200320032003 and 2004200420042004. The original paper document was consistent, but some symbol recognition errors occurred during the digitizing phase, as constraints 1) and 2) are not satisfied on the acquired data for year 2003200320032003, that is:

  • i)

    in section Receipts, the aggregate value of total cash receipts is not equal to the sum of detail values of the same section.

  • ii)

    the value of net cash inflow is not to equal the difference between total cash receipts and total disbursements.

In order to exploit the digital version of the cash budget, a fundamental issue is to define a reasonable strategy for locating OCR errors, and then ‚Äúrepairing‚Äù the acquired data to extract reliable information.

Most of well-known techniques for repairing data violating either key constraints or functional dependencies accomplish this task by performing deletions and insertions of tuples. Indeed this approach is not suitable for contexts analogous to that of Example¬†1, that is of data acquired by OCR tools from paper documents. For instance, repairing Table 1 by either adding or removing rows means hypothesizing that the OCR tool either jumped a row or ‚Äúinvented‚Äù it when acquiring the source paper document, which is rather unrealistic. The same issue arises in other scenarios dealing with numerical data representing pieces of information acquired automatically, such as sensor networks. In a sensor network with error-free communication channels, no reading generated by sensors can be lost, thus repairing the database by adding new readings (as well as removing collected ones) is of no sense. In this kind of scenario, the most natural approach to data repairing is updating directly the numerical data: this means working at attribute-level, rather than at tuple-level. For instance, in the case of Example 1, we can reasonably assume that inconsistencies of digitized data are due to symbol recognition errors, and thus trying to re-construct actual data values is well founded. Likewise, in the case of sensor readings violating aggregate constraints, we can hypothesize that inconsistency is due to some trouble occurred at a sensor while generating some reading, thus repairing data by modifying readings instead of deleting (or inserting) them is justified.

1.1 Related Work

First theoretical approaches to the problem of dealing with incomplete and inconsistent information date back to 80s, but these works mainly focus on issues related to the semantics of incompleteness [12]. The problem of extracting reliable information from inconsistent data was first addressed in [4], where an extension of relational algebra (namely flexible algebra) was proposed to evaluate queries on data inconsistent w.r.t. key constraints (i.e. tuples having the same values for key attributes, but conflicting values for other attributes). The first proof-theoretic notion of consistent query answer was introduced in [6], expressing the idea that tuples involved in an integrity violation should not be considered in the evaluation of consistent query answering. In [1] a different notion of consistent answer was introduced, based on the notion of repair: a repair of an inconsistent database Dùê∑Ditalic_D is a database D‚Ä≤superscriptùê∑‚Ä≤D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfying the given integrity constraints and which is minimally different from Dùê∑Ditalic_D. Thus, the consistent answer of a query qùëûqitalic_q posed on Dùê∑Ditalic_D is the answer which is in every result of qùëûqitalic_q on each repair D‚Ä≤superscriptùê∑‚Ä≤D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In particular, in [1] the authors show that, for restricted classes of queries and constraints, consistent answers can be evaluated without computing repairs, but by looking only at the specified constraints and rewriting the original query qùëûqitalic_q into a query q‚Ä≤superscriptùëû‚Ä≤q^{\prime}italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that the answer of q‚Ä≤superscriptùëû‚Ä≤q^{\prime}italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on Dùê∑Ditalic_D is equal to the consistent answer of qùëûqitalic_q on Dùê∑Ditalic_D. Based on the notions of repair and consistent query answer introduced in [1], several works investigated more expressive classes of queries and constraints. In [2] extended disjunctive logic programs with exceptions were used for the computation of repairs, and in [3] the evaluation of aggregate queries on inconsistent data was investigated. A further generalization was proposed in [11], where the authors defined a technique based on the rewriting of constraints into extended disjunctive rules with two different forms of negation (negation as failure and classical negation). This technique was shown to be sound and complete for universally quantified constraints.

All the above-cited approaches assume that tuple insertions and deletions are the basic primitives for repairing inconsistent data. More recently, in [9] a repairing strategy using only tuple deletions was proposed, and in [17] repairs also consisting of update operations were considered. The latter is the first approach performing repairs at the attribute-value level, but is not well-suited in our context, as it works only in the case that constraints consist of full dependencies.

The first work investigating aggregate constraints on numerical data is [16], where the consistency problem of very general forms of aggregation is considered, but no issue related to data-repairing is investigated. In [5] the problem of repairing databases by fixing numerical data at attribute level is investigated. The authors show that deciding the existence of a repair under both denial constraints (where built-in comparison predicates are allowed) and a non-linear form of multi-attribute aggregate constraints is undecidable. Then they disregard aggregate constraints and focus on the problem of repairing data violating denial constraints, where no form of aggregation is allowed in the adopted constraints.

1.2 Main Contribution

We investigate the problem of repairing and extracting reliable information from data violating a given set of aggregate constraints. These constraints consist of linear inequalities on aggregate-sum queries issued on measure values stored in the database. This syntactic form enables meaningful constraints to be expressed, such as those of Example 1 as well as other forms which often occur in practice.

We consider database repairs consisting of ‚Äúreasonable‚Äù sets of value-update operations aiming at re-constructing the correct measure values of inconsistent data. We adopt two different criteria for determining whether a set of update operations repairing data can be considered ‚Äúreasonable‚Äù or not: set-minimal semantics and card-minimal semantics. Both these semantics aim at preserving the information represented in the source data as much as possible. They correspond to different repairing strategies which turn out to be well-suited for different application scenarios.

We provide the complexity characterization of three fundamental problems: i) repairability (is there at least one repair for the given database w.r.t. the specified constraints?); ii) repair checking (given a set of update operations, is it a ‚Äúreasonable‚Äù repair?); iii) consistent query answer (is a given boolean query true in every ‚Äúreasonable‚Äù repair?).

Definition 1 (Aggregate constraint)

Given a database scheme ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, an aggregate constraint on ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D is an expression of the form:

‚àÄx1,‚Ä¶,xk‚Å¢(œï‚Å¢(x1,‚Ä¶,xk)‚üπ‚àëi=1nci‚ãÖœái‚Å¢(Xi)‚â§K)for-allsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëòitalic-œïsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõ‚ãÖsubscriptùëêùëñsubscriptùúíùëñsubscriptùëãùëñùêæ\forall x_{1},\dots,x_{k}\ \left(\phi(x_{1},\dots,x_{k})\implies\sum_{i=1}^{n}c_{i}\cdot\chi_{i}(X_{i})\leq K\right)‚àÄ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œï ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚üπ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_œá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚â§ italic_K ) (1)

where:

Observe that aggregate constraints enable equalities to be expressed as well, since an equality can be viewed as a pair of inequalities. For the sake of brevity, in the following equalities will be written explicitly.

2.2 Updates

Updates at attribute-level will be used in the following as the basic primitives for repairing data violating aggregate constraints. Given a relational scheme RùëÖRitalic_R in the database scheme ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, let ‚Ñ≥R={A1,‚Ä¶,Ak}subscript‚Ñ≥ùëÖsubscriptùê¥1‚Ä¶subscriptùê¥ùëò\mathcal{M}_{R}=\{A_{1},\dots,A_{k}\}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } be the subset of ‚Ñ≥ùíüsubscript‚Ñ≥ùíü\mathcal{M_{D}}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT containing all the attributes in RùëÖRitalic_R belonging to ‚Ñ≥ùíüsubscript‚Ñ≥ùíü\mathcal{M_{D}}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Observe that atomic updates work on the set ‚Ñ≥Rsubscript‚Ñ≥ùëÖ\mathcal{M}_{R}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of measure attributes, as our framework is based on the assumption that data inconsistency is due to errors in the acquisition phase (as in the case of digitization of paper documents) or in the measurement phase (as in the case of sensor readings). Therefore our approach will only consider repairs aiming at re-constructing the correct measures.

Example 5

Definition 3 (Consistent database update)

Let Dùê∑Ditalic_D be a database and U={u1,‚Ä¶,un}ùëàsubscriptùë¢1‚Ä¶subscriptùë¢ùëõU=\{u_{1},\dots,u_{n}\}italic_U = { italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } be a set of atomic updates on tuples of Dùê∑Ditalic_D. 3 Repairing inconsistent databases

Definition 4 (Repair)

Let ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D be a database scheme, ùíú‚Å¢ùíûùíúùíû\mathcal{AC}caligraphic_A caligraphic_C a set of aggregate constraints on ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, and Dùê∑Ditalic_D an instance of ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D such that D‚äßÃ∏ùíú‚Å¢ùíûnot-modelsùê∑ùíúùíûD\not\models\mathcal{AC}italic_D ‚äßÃ∏ caligraphic_A caligraphic_C. A repair œÅùúå\rhoitalic_œÅ for Dùê∑Ditalic_D is a consistent database update such that œÅ‚Å¢(D)‚äßùíú‚Å¢ùíûmodelsùúåùê∑ùíúùíû\rho(D)\models\mathcal{AC}italic_œÅ ( italic_D ) ‚äß caligraphic_A caligraphic_C.

Example 6

A repair œÅùúå\rhoitalic_œÅ for CashBudget w.r.t. constraints 1), 2) and 3) consists in decreasing attribute Value in the tuple t=CashBudget(2003, Receipts, total cash receipts,t=\mbox{CashBudget}(\mbox{2003, Receipts, total cash receipts,}italic_t = CashBudget ( 2003, Receipts, total cash receipts, aggr, 250)\mbox{aggr, 250})aggr, 250 ) down to 220; that is, œÅ={<t,Value,220>}\rho=\{\ <t,\mbox{\emph{Value}},220>\ \}italic_œÅ = { < italic_t , Value , 220 > }.

We now characterize the complexity of the repair-existence problem. All the complexity results in the paper refer to data-complexity, that is the size of the constraints is assumed to be bounded by a constant.

The following lemma is a preliminary result which states that potential repairs for an inconsistent database can be found among set of updates whose size is polynomially bounded by the size of the original database.

Theorem 3.1 (Repair existence)

Let ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D be a database scheme, ùíú‚Å¢ùíûùíúùíû\mathcal{AC}caligraphic_A caligraphic_C a set of aggregate constraints on ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, and Dùê∑Ditalic_D an instance of ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D such that D‚äßÃ∏ùíúùíûnot-modelsùê∑ùíúùíûD\not\models\mbox{\cal AC}italic_D ‚äßÃ∏ AC. The problem of deciding whether there is a repair for Dùê∑Ditalic_D is NP-complete.

Proof

Membership. A polynomial size witness for deciding the existence of a repair is a database update UùëàUitalic_U on Dùê∑Ditalic_D: testing whether UùëàUitalic_U is a repair for Dùê∑Ditalic_D means verifying U‚Å¢(D)‚äßùíú‚Å¢ùíûmodelsùëàùê∑ùíúùíûU(D)\models\mathcal{AC}italic_U ( italic_D ) ‚äß caligraphic_A caligraphic_C, which can be accomplished in polynomial time w.r.t. the size of Dùê∑Ditalic_D and UùëàUitalic_U. If a repair exists for Dùê∑Ditalic_D, then Lemma 1 guarantees that a polynomial size repair for Dùê∑Ditalic_D exists too.
Hardness. We show a reduction from circuit sat to our problem. Without loss of generality, we consider a boolean circuit Cùê∂Citalic_C using only NOR gates. Remark. Theorem 3.1 states that the repair existence problem is decidable. This result, together with the practical usefulness of the considered class of constraints, makes the complexity analysis of finding consistent answers on inconsistent data interesting. Basically decidability results from the linear nature of the considered constraints. If products between two attributes were allowed as attribute expressions, the repair-existence problem would be undecidable (this can be proved straightforwardly, since this form of non-linear constraints is more expressive than those introduced in [5], where the corresponding repair-existence problem was shown to be undecidable). However, observe that occurrences of products of the form Ai√óAjsubscriptùê¥ùëñsubscriptùê¥ùëóA_{i}\times A_{j}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT √ó italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in attribute expressions can lead to undecidability only if both Aisubscriptùê¥ùëñA_{i}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ajsubscriptùê¥ùëóA_{j}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are measure attribute. Otherwise, this case is equivalent to products of the form c√óAùëêùê¥c\times Aitalic_c √ó italic_A, which can be expressed in our form of aggregate constraints.

3.1 Minimal repairs

Theorem 3.1 deals with the problem of deciding whether a database Dùê∑Ditalic_D violating a set of aggregate constraints ùíú‚Å¢ùíûùíúùíû\mathcal{AC}caligraphic_A caligraphic_C can be repaired. If this is the case, different repairs can be performed on Dùê∑Ditalic_D yielding a new database consistent w.r.t. ùíú‚Å¢ùíûùíúùíû\mathcal{AC}caligraphic_A caligraphic_C, although not all of them can be considered ‚Äúreasonable‚Äù. For instance, if a repair exists for Dùê∑Ditalic_D changing only one value in one tuple of Dùê∑Ditalic_D, any repair updating all values in all tuples of Dùê∑Ditalic_D can be reasonably disregarded. To evaluate whether a repair should be considered ‚Äúrelevant‚Äù or not, we introduce two different ordering criteria on repairs, corresponding to the comparison operators ‚Äò‚â§setsubscriptset\leq_{\mbox{\scriptsize\emph{set}}}‚â§ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT set end_POSTSUBSCRIPT‚Äô and ‚Äò‚â§cardsubscriptcard\leq_{\mbox{\scriptsize\emph{card}}}‚â§ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT card end_POSTSUBSCRIPT‚Äô. The former compares two repairs by evaluating whether one of the two performs a subset of the updates of the other. That is, given two repairs œÅ1subscriptùúå1\rho_{1}italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, œÅ2subscriptùúå2\rho_{2}italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we say that œÅ1subscriptùúå1\rho_{1}italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT precedes œÅ2subscriptùúå2\rho_{2}italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (œÅ1‚â§setœÅ2subscriptsetsubscriptùúå1subscriptùúå2\rho_{1}\leq_{\mbox{\scriptsize\emph{set}}}\rho_{2}italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT set end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) iff Œª‚Å¢(œÅ1)‚äÜŒª‚Å¢(œÅ2)ùúÜsubscriptùúå1ùúÜsubscriptùúå2\lambda(\rho_{1})\subseteq\lambda(\rho_{2})italic_Œª ( italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚äÜ italic_Œª ( italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). The latter ordering criterion states that a repair œÅ1subscriptùúå1\rho_{1}italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is preferred w.r.t. a repair œÅ2subscriptùúå2\rho_{2}italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (œÅ1‚â§cardœÅ2subscriptcardsubscriptùúå1subscriptùúå2\rho_{1}\leq_{\mbox{\scriptsize\emph{card}}}\rho_{2}italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT card end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) iff |Œª‚Å¢(œÅ1)|‚â§|Œª‚Å¢(œÅ2)|ùúÜsubscriptùúå1ùúÜsubscriptùúå2|\lambda(\rho_{1})|\leq|\lambda(\rho_{2})|| italic_Œª ( italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | ‚â§ | italic_Œª ( italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) |, that is if the number of changes issued by œÅ1subscriptùúå1\rho_{1}italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is less than œÅ2subscriptùúå2\rho_{2}italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Observe that œÅ1<setœÅ2subscriptsetsubscriptùúå1subscriptùúå2\rho_{1}\!\!<_{\mbox{\scriptsize\emph{set}}}\!\rho_{2}italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < start_POSTSUBSCRIPT set end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT implies œÅ1<cardœÅ2subscriptcardsubscriptùúå1subscriptùúå2\rho_{1}\!\!<_{\mbox{\scriptsize\emph{card}}}\!\rho_{2}italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < start_POSTSUBSCRIPT card end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, but the vice versa does not hold, as it can be the case that repair œÅ1subscriptùúå1\rho_{1}italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT changes a set of values Œª‚Å¢(œÅ1)ùúÜsubscriptùúå1\lambda(\rho_{1})italic_Œª ( italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) which is not subset of Œª‚Å¢(œÅ2)ùúÜsubscriptùúå2\lambda(\rho_{2})italic_Œª ( italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), but having cardinality less than Œª‚Å¢(œÅ2)ùúÜsubscriptùúå2\lambda(\rho_{2})italic_Œª ( italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

Theorem 3.2 (Minimal-repair checking)

Let ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D be a database scheme, ùíú‚Å¢ùíûùíúùíû\mathcal{AC}caligraphic_A caligraphic_C a set of aggregate constraints on ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, and Dùê∑Ditalic_D be an instance of ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D such that D‚äßÃ∏ùíú‚Å¢ùíûnot-modelsùê∑ùíúùíûD\not\models\mathcal{AC}italic_D ‚äßÃ∏ caligraphic_A caligraphic_C. Given a repair œÅùúå\rhoitalic_œÅ for Dùê∑Ditalic_D w.r.t. ùíú‚Å¢ùíûùíúùíû\mathcal{AC}caligraphic_A caligraphic_C, deciding whether œÅùúå\rhoitalic_œÅ is minimal (under both the card-minimality and set-minimality semantics) is coNP-complete.

Set-minimality vs card-minimality¬†
Basically, both the set-minimal and the card-minimal semantics aim at considering ‚Äúreasonable‚Äù repairs which preserve the content of the input database as much as possible. To the best of our knowledge the notion of repair minimality based on the number of performed updates has not been used in the context of relational data violating ‚Äúnon-numerical‚Äù constraints (such as keys, foreign keys, and functional dependencies). In this context, most of the proposed approaches consider repairs consisting of deletions and insertions of tuples, and preferred repairs are those consisting of minimal sets of insert/delete operations. In fact, the set-minimal semantics is more natural than the card-minimal one when no hypothesis can be reasonably formulated to ‚Äúguess‚Äù how data inconsistency occurred, which is the case of previous works on database-repairing. As it will be clear in the following, in the general case, the adoption of the card-minimal semantics could make reasonable sets of delete/insert operations to be not considered as candidate repairs, even if they correspond to error configurations which cannot be excluded.

For instance, consider a relational scheme Department(Name, Area, Employers, Category) where the following functional dependencies are defined: F‚Å¢D1:A‚Å¢r‚Å¢e‚Å¢a‚ÜíE‚Å¢m‚Å¢p‚Å¢l‚Å¢o‚Å¢y‚Å¢e‚Å¢r‚Å¢s:ùêπsubscriptùê∑1‚Üíùê¥ùëüùëíùëéùê∏ùëöùëùùëôùëúùë¶ùëíùëüùë†FD_{1}:Area\rightarrow Employersitalic_F italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_A italic_r italic_e italic_a ‚Üí italic_E italic_m italic_p italic_l italic_o italic_y italic_e italic_r italic_s (i.e. departments having the same area must have the same number of employers) and F‚Å¢D2:E‚Å¢m‚Å¢p‚Å¢l‚Å¢o‚Å¢y‚Å¢e‚Å¢r‚Å¢s‚ÜíC‚Å¢a‚Å¢t‚Å¢e‚Å¢g‚Å¢o‚Å¢r‚Å¢y:ùêπsubscriptùê∑2‚Üíùê∏ùëöùëùùëôùëúùë¶ùëíùëüùë†ùê∂ùëéùë°ùëíùëîùëúùëüùë¶FD_{2}:Employers\rightarrow Categoryitalic_F italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_E italic_m italic_p italic_l italic_o italic_y italic_e italic_r italic_s ‚Üí italic_C italic_a italic_t italic_e italic_g italic_o italic_r italic_y (i.e. departments with the same number of employers must be of the same category). Consider the following relation:

Department Area Employers Category
D1subscriptùê∑1D_{1}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT 100 24 A ‚ü∂t1‚ü∂absentsubscriptùë°1\longrightarrow t_{1}‚ü∂ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
D2subscriptùê∑2D_{2}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT 100 30 B ‚ü∂t2‚ü∂absentsubscriptùë°2\longrightarrow t_{2}‚ü∂ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

Relation above does not satisfy F‚Å¢D1ùêπsubscriptùê∑1FD_{1}italic_F italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as the three departments occupy the same area but do not have the same number of employers. Suppose we are using a repairing strategy based on deletions and insertions of tuples. Different repairs can be adopted. For instance, if we suppose that the inconsistency arises as tuple t1subscriptùë°1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains wrong information, Department can be repaired by only deleting t1subscriptùë°1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Otherwise, if we assume that t1subscriptùë°1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is correct, a possible repair consists of deleting t2subscriptùë°2t_{2}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and t3subscriptùë°3t_{3}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. If the card-minimal semantics is adopted, the latter strategy will be disregarded, as it performs two deletions, whereas the former deletes only one tuple. On the contrary, if the set-minimal semantics is adopted, both the two strategies define minimal repairs (as the sets of tuples deleted by each of these strategies are not subsets of one another). In fact, if we do not know how the error occurred, there is no reason to assume that the error configuration corresponding to the second repairing strategy is not possible. Indeed, inconsistency could be due to integrating data coming from different sources, where some sources are not up-to-date. However, there is no good reason to assume that the source which contains the smallest number of tuples is the one that is up to date. See [13] for a survey on inconsistency due to data integration.

Likewise, the card-minimal semantics could disregard reasonable repairs also in the case that a repairing strategy based on updating values instead of deleting/inserting whole tuples is adopted 111Value updates cannot be necessarily simulated as a sequence deletion/insertion, as this might not be minimal under set inclusion.. For instance, if we suppose that the inconsistency arises as the value of attribute Area is wrong for either t1subscriptùë°1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or both t2subscriptùë°2t_{2}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and t3subscriptùë°3t_{3}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Department can be repaired by replacing the Area value for either t1subscriptùë°1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or both t2subscriptùë°2t_{2}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and t3subscriptùë°3t_{3}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with a value different from 100100100100. Otherwise, if we assume that the Area values for all the tuples are correct, Department can be repaired w.r.t. F‚Å¢D1ùêπsubscriptùê∑1FD_{1}italic_F italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by making the Employers value of t1subscriptùë°1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT equal to that of t2subscriptùë°2t_{2}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and t3subscriptùë°3t_{3}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Indeed this update yields a relation which does not satisfy F‚Å¢D2ùêπsubscriptùê∑2FD_{2}italic_F italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (as t1‚Å¢[Category]‚â†t2‚Å¢[Category]subscriptùë°1delimited-[]Categorysubscriptùë°2delimited-[]Categoryt_{1}[\mbox{\emph{Category}}]\neq t_{2}[\mbox{\emph{Category}}]italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ Category ] ‚â† italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ Category ]) so that another value update is necessary in order to make it consistent. Under the card-minimal semantics the latter strategy is disregarded, as it performs more than one value update, whereas the former changes only the Area value of one tuple. On the contrary, under the set-minimal semantics both the two strategies define minimal repairs (as the sets of updates issued by each of these strategies are not subsets of one another). As for the case explained above, disregarding the second repairing strategy is arbitrary, if we do not know how the error occurred.

Our framework addresses scenarios where also card-minimal semantics can be reasonable. For instance, if we assume that integrity violations are generated while acquiring data by means of an automatic or semi-automatic system (e.g. an OCR digitizing a paper document, a sensor monitoring atmospheric conditions, etc.), focusing on error configurations which can be repaired with the minimum number of updates is well founded. Indeed this corresponds to the case that the acquiring system made the minimum number of errors (e.g. bad symbol-recognition for an OCR, sensor troubles, etc.), which can be considered the most probable event.

In this work we discuss the existence of repairs, and their computation under both card-minimal and set-minimal semantics. The latter has to be preferred when no warranty is given on the accuracy of acquiring tools, and, more generally, when no hypothesis can be formulated on the cause of errors.

3.2 Consistent query answers

In this section we address the problem of extracting reliable information from data violating a given set of aggregate constraints. We consider boolean queries checking whether a given tuple belongs to a database, and adopt the widely-used notion of consistent query answer introduced in [1].

Definition 6 (Query)

A query over a database scheme ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D is a ground atom of the form R‚Å¢(v1,‚Ä¶,vn)ùëÖsubscriptùë£1‚Ä¶subscriptùë£ùëõR(v_{1},\dots,v_{n})italic_R ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where R‚Å¢(A1,‚Ä¶,An)ùëÖsubscriptùê¥1‚Ä¶subscriptùê¥ùëõR(A_{1},\dots,A_{n})italic_R ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a relational scheme in ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D.

Definition 7 (Consistent query answer)

Let ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D be a database scheme, Dùê∑Ditalic_D be an instance of ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, ùíú‚Å¢ùíûùíúùíû\mathcal{AC}caligraphic_A caligraphic_C be a set of aggregate constraints on ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D and qùëûqitalic_q be a query over ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D. The consistent query answer of qùëûqitalic_q on Dùê∑Ditalic_D under the set-minimal semantics [resp. card-minimal semantics] is true iff q‚ààœÅ‚Å¢(D)ùëûùúåùê∑q\in\rho(D)italic_q ‚àà italic_œÅ ( italic_D ) for each œÅ‚ààœÅMsetùúåsuperscriptsubscriptùúåùëÄset\rho\in\rho_{M}^{\mbox{\scriptsize set}}italic_œÅ ‚àà italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT set end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [resp. for each œÅ‚ààœÅMcardùúåsuperscriptsubscriptùúåùëÄcard\rho\in\rho_{M}^{\mbox{\scriptsize card}}italic_œÅ ‚àà italic_œÅ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT card end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT].

The consistent query answers of a query qùëûqitalic_q issued on the database Dùê∑Ditalic_D under the set-minimal and card-minimal semantics will be denoted as qs‚Å¢e‚Å¢t‚Å¢(D)superscriptùëûùë†ùëíùë°ùê∑q^{set}(D)italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_e italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_D ) and qc‚Å¢a‚Å¢r‚Å¢d‚Å¢(D)superscriptùëûùëêùëéùëüùëëùê∑q^{card}(D)italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c italic_a italic_r italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_D ), respectively.

Theorem 3.3 (Consistent query answer under set-minimal semantics)

Let ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D be a database scheme, Dùê∑Ditalic_D be an instance of ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, ùíú‚Å¢ùíûùíúùíû\mathcal{AC}caligraphic_A caligraphic_C be a set of aggregate constraints on ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D and qùëûqitalic_q be a query over Dùê∑Ditalic_D. Conclusions and Future Work

We have addressed the problem of repairing and extracting reliable information from numerical databases violating aggregate constraints, thus filling a gap in previous works dealing with inconsistent data, where only traditional forms of constraints (such as keys, foreign keys, etc.) were considered. In fact, aggregate constraints frequently occur in many real-life scenarios where guaranteeing the consistency of numerical data is mandatory. In particular, we have considered aggregate constraints defined as sets of linear inequalities on aggregate-sum queries on input data. For this class of constraints we have characterized the complexity of several issues related to the computation of consistent query answers.

Future work will be devoted to the identification of decidable cases when more expressive forms of constraint are adopted, that allow products between attribute values (as explained in the paper, enabling non-linear forms of aggregate expressions makes the repair-existence problem undecidable in the general case). Moreover the design of efficient algorithms for computing consistent answers will be addressed.

(Hardness). Hardness can be proved by showing a reduction from the following implication problem in the context of propositional logic over a finite domain VùëâVitalic_V: ‚Äúgiven an atomic knowledge base TùëáTitalic_T on VùëâVitalic_V, a formula QùëÑQitalic_Q on TùëáTitalic_T and a formula pùëùpitalic_p on VùëâVitalic_V, decide whether QùëÑQitalic_Q is derivable from every model in T‚àòDpsubscriptùê∑ùëáùëùT\circ_{D}pitalic_T ‚àò start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p‚Äù, where T‚àòDpsubscriptùê∑ùëáùëùT\circ_{D}pitalic_T ‚àò start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p is the updated (or revised) knowledge base according to the Dalal‚Äôs revision operator. Œî2p‚Å¢[l‚Å¢o‚Å¢g‚Å¢n]superscriptsubscriptŒî2ùëùdelimited-[]ùëôùëúùëîùëõ\Delta_{2}^{p}[log\ n]roman_Œî start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_l italic_o italic_g italic_n ]-completeness of this problem was shown in [10].
